description: The novelist, essayist, critic and author, most recently, of White Sands says reading William Finnegans Barbarian Days made him realize his whole life has been pretty much a waste. I suspected this anyway.

title: How to Swallow a Sword
description: Tilt your head back, tucking in your chin until your mouth and esophagus align with your spine. Get everything in a straight line, says Dai Andrews, who travels the world as a sword-swallowing performer. Under the guidance of a mentor, begin with a blunt object. Many novices start with a metal clothes hanger bent straight. Learn to control your gag reflex by desensitizing it with regular practice and cultivating what Andrews calls mind-body connection. Practice tai chi, yoga, meditation, anything that trains you to see fear arising  or the need to retch  and serenely let those feelings pass. If you have a sword inside you and you panic, Andrews says, you need to remain still.

title: Vito Acconci Invites You to Watch Him as He Watches Us
description: Vito Acconci, who bushwhacked the path to video art in New York in the 1960s and early 1970s, makes many of todays young artists look tame. The nearly 60 short videos in Vito Acconci: Where We Are Now (Who Are We Anyway?), 1976, the excellent early-career survey at MoMA PS1, manage to be unnervingly funny, pathetically gross and politically razor-sharp. And even with a decades-old patina of age, theyre still too funky to fit into MoMAs scrubbed white Manhattan premises.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Too Many Trips to Ohio With Your Baby
description: Alex writes: My wife and I are from Ohio, and we moved to Belmont, Mass., six years ago. We have a 20-month-old daughter, and my wife feels our families are missing out, so she thinks we should visit Ohio once every couple of months. I argue that three times a year is plenty.

title: How Polling Can Go Wrong
description: When people complain to me about a poll, its usually because they think the demographics are wrong. The pollsters polled too many white people, commenters might say, or too many old people. Or perhaps the sample of Hispanic voters doesnt seem quite Democratic enough.

title: Democratic Group Prepares Trove of Research to Unload on Donald Trump
description: The opposition research group American Bridge made its mark in the 2012 election cycle with a video clip of a Missouri Senate candidate, Todd Akin, saying that legitimate rape rarely leads to pregnancy.

title: Return of the Sun King
description: Taste in works of art, writes the Duchess of Devonshire in my dog-eared copy of her 2011 collection, All in One Basket  where Ive heavily marked her feelings about chickens, plastic packaging, guests stealing books, plumbing, the Turner prize and Elvis  is notoriously susceptible to fashion.

title: Our Agreement
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Maxwell Is on His Own Timetable
description: The first time Maxwell disappeared, he was gone about eight years. After starting his career in the mid-90s with three platinum albums in a row, each delivered punctually, this soul and R&B singer all but vanished. He opted not to tour and didnt release the expected follow-up to Now, from 2001. Instead, he faded into near anonymity.

title: In the Russian Army, With Lust
description: By the time I joined the Russian Army two years ago, I was much older than the average recruit. At 25, I had eluded obligatory military service for years. But being born into the family of a career officer and war correspondent, I had also continually endured a sense of guilt for failing to meet my duty in serving my motherland.

title: The Secrets in Guatemalas Bones
description: One afternoon in 1994, during his senior year in college, Fredy Peccerelli sat at an anthropology conference in Atlanta and stared at the man onstage. Peccerelli had seen the renowned bone detective Clyde Snow before, but only in a textbook. Snow, who was in his 60s, leaned forward at the lectern, speaking in his genial Texas drawl about blindfolded skulls and bodies dumped in clandestine graves. He wore his usual attire of an Irish tweed jacket, cowboy boots and a fedora.

title: Review: In The BFG, Walking Gently and Wearing Huge Shoes
description: The BFG  it stands for big friendly giant  is a small, friendly movie, an attempt to reconcile the scale and dazzle of modern filmmaking with the quiet, mischievous charm of Roald Dahls book. Directed by Steven Spielberg and written by his frequent collaborator Melissa Mathison (who died in November), it chronicles the relationship between the title character (Mark Rylance) and a young orphan named Sophie (Ruby Barnhill).

title: Not Forgotten: Upton Sinclair, Whose Muckraking Changed the Meat Industry
description: Sinclairs novel The Jungle spurred public outrage that led to legislation in 1906 aimed at regulating the food and drug industries.

title: Brexit Briefing: Boris Johnson Isnt Running; Jeremy Corbyn Seeks Labour Revolution
description: LONDON  The Conservative Party (and by extension, Britain itself) is moving a step closer to a new leader. Members of the opposition Labour Party are wondering if their leader, Jeremy Corbyn, will save them or plunge the party into irrelevancy.

title: How Much Do We Love TV? Let Us Count the Ways
description: You still love television. You use your tablet more than ever. And now you are as likely to have paid services like Netflix or Amazon Prime as you are to have a DVR service.

title: Meryl Streep, Diane Lane and Others on the Legacy of Elizabeth Swados
description: For Elizabeth Swados, being nominated for four Tony Awards in one year while still in her 20s  for Runaways, in 1978  led to success in an unexpected direction. Or, rather, in several unexpected directions.

title: $7 for Corn Flakes? Cereal Gets Makeover at Kelloggs Store in Times Square
description: Cereal is going upscale.

title: Turkey Says Airport Bombers Were From Kyrgyzstan, Russia and Uzbekistan
description: ISTANBUL  The three suicide bombers who killed 44 people at Istanbuls main international airport this week have been identified as citizens of Russia, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan, Turkish officials said Thursday.

title: Taliban Attack on Afghan Police Cadets Kills at Least 33
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents bombed a convoy of buses carrying police cadets on the outskirts of Kabul, the Afghan capital, on Thursday, killing at least 33 people, including four civilians, according to government officials and the United Nations.

title: In Syria, Starving Instead of Fasting
description: Every Ramadan, Husseins grandmother cooks him fatayer, a savory pastry stuffed with cheese or meat and baked in an oven. This year, she replaced the filling with grass and cooked the dish on a fire of burning plastic. I promise you, it tasted better than it sounds, Hussein told me last week, just after he broke his fast.

title: Beijing Police Officers Arrested in Environmentalists Death
description: BEIJING  In an unusual case of official action against the police, Beijing prosecutors said on Thursday that two officers had been arrested on charges of dereliction of duty that led to the death of a 29-year-old man in their custody.

title: Is This Between Friends?
description: Dear Diary:

title: California Today: Sorry, Folks, Parks Closed
description: Good morning.

title: Gay Marriage, a Year Later
description: In June 2015, the Supreme Court made same-sex marriage legal nationwide. Readers who were married after the ruling reflected on the past year. Here is a selection.

title: 9 in Navy Disciplined Over Irans Capture of Sailors
description: WASHINGTON  Four hours behind schedule and 300 miles from their destination in Bahrain, the crews of two Navy patrol boats figured they had to make up time somehow. Immediately after leaving port in Kuwait, they veered off their planned route through the Persian Gulf, and their troubles began.

title: Cheryl Strayed: A Close Encounter at Badlands
description: Over 300 million people visited the national parks system in 2015  and many left with indelible memories. In anticipation of the park system turning 100 in August, we asked five writers  three novelists, a memoirist and a poet  to recount times when a national park left a mark on their lives.

title: U.S. Criticizes Myanmar Over Human Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday listed Myanmar as among the worst offenders in human trafficking, consigning a country President Obama only four years ago brought in from the diplomatic cold to the same ranking as Iran, North Korea and Syria.

title: Glacier National Park: Return Trips
description: Over 300 million people visited the national parks system in 2015  and many left with indelible memories. In anticipation of the park system turning 100 in August, we asked five writers  three novelists, a memoirist and a poet  to recount times when a national park left a mark on their lives.

title: Grand Teton National Park: Truth in Beauty
description: Over 300 million people visited the national parks system in 2015  and many left with indelible memories. In anticipation of the park system turning 100 in August, we asked five writers  three novelists, a memoirist and a poet  to recount times when a national park left a mark on their lives.

title: Grand Canyon National Park: An Absence of World
description: Over 300 million people visited the national parks system in 2015  and many left with indelible memories. In anticipation of the park system turning 100 in August, we asked five writers  three novelists, a memoirist and a poet  to recount times when a national park left a mark on their lives.

title: Acadia National Park: Maines Bright Face
description: Over 300 million people visited the national parks system in 2015  and many left with indelible memories. In anticipation of the park system turning 100 in August, we asked five writers  three novelists, a memoirist and a poet  to recount times when a national park left a mark on their lives.

title: Political Winner in Britain: Far Right, at Labours Expense
description: LONDON  In the chaos that has followed Britains vote to leave the European Union, the political winner so far has been Nigel Farage, the provocateur who is the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, or UKIP.

title: Midnighter & Apollo, Gay Superheroes of Comics, to Reunite This Fall
description: Gay Pride Month ends today, but DC Comics is giving fans something to look forward to this fall. In October the company will publish Midnighter & Apollo, the first part of a six-issue mini-series that reunites the two heroes, who are gay and have an on-again off-again relationship.

title: Spanish Tax Authorities Investigate Google
description: The Spanish authorities have opened a new investigation into possible tax evasion by Google, broadening the scrutiny of the American technology giant in Europe.

title: Taliban Bombs Convoy of Buses
description: At least 33 people were killed and more were injured when the Taliban bombed buses carrying police cadets on the outskirts of Kabul, Afghanistan, on Thursday.

title: Taiwan-Owned Steel Factory Caused Toxic Spill, Vietnam Says
description: BANGKOK  The government of Vietnam, breaking its silence about a huge fish kill in April, said on Thursday that the coastal disaster was caused by a Taiwan-owned steel factory that discharged a combination of chemicals, including cyanide, into the ocean.

title: Chris Christie Becomes Powerful Figure in Donald Trump Campaign
description: Defeated by Donald J. Trump in the 2016 primaries and derided by fellow Republicans for his subsequent embrace of Mr. Trump, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has quietly emerged as one of the most influential advisers to his partys presumptive presidential nominee and one of the leading contenders to be his running mate.

title: Lionsgate to Acquire Starz, a Pay Channel, for $4.4 Billion
description: The movie studio Lionsgate agreed on Thursday to buy Starz, the premium cable channel home to hit shows like Outlander, for about $4.4 billion in the latest round of media consolidation.

title: Naked Man in Times Square Taunts and Spits at Police, as Cameras Roll
description: A naked man who taunted and spat at the police from atop the TKTS booth in Times Square became a rush-hour distraction and a social media spectacle for nearly an hour on Thursday as bystanders recorded video of his actions before he fell about three stories to the ground.

title: 1966: Soviets and French Seek Peace
description: MOSCOW  The Soviet Union and France declared their intention tonight [June 30] to try bringing security and lasting peace to Europe. The agreement came in a declaration ceremoniously signed by French President Charles de Gaulle and Soviet President Nikolai V. Podgorny in the great Kremlin Palace on the last night of the French leaders 11-day state visit. Along with the declaration the presidents watched as Foreign Ministers Andrei Gromyko and Maurice Couve de Murville signed agreements on a joint space research program and scientific and technical cooperation.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 1, 1966

title: Memorials for Victims of Istanbul Attack
description: People in Istanbul on Thursday mourned the victims of Tuesday's terrorist attack on the Ataturk Airport.

title: Estimate of U.S. Transgender Population Doubles to 1.4 Million Adults
description: About 1.4 million adults in the United States identify as transgender, double a widely used previous estimate, according to an analysis based on new federal and state data.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: The News with Andrew Rosenthal
description: Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Trey Gowdy and the Bengazi report, terror in Turkey, Brexit and the Supreme Court abortion decision.

title: Feeling Stung by a Fickle Friend Named Facebook
description: Facebooks relationship with the media industry is a bit like the old fable of the scorpion and the frog.

title: Joint Base Andrews Locked Down After Unfounded Gunman Report
description: The word ricocheted around the world at internet speed Thursday morning: Joint Base Andrews, best known as home to Air Force One, was on lockdown because of reports of an active shooter. Security forces scrambled, cable news zeroed in, a flight by the vice president was put off, and Twitter users repeated thirdhand reports of a gunman holed up in a bathroom.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 2 Through 10
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Retrieving Your Google Photos
description: Q. I like having the automatic online backup and storage for my pictures with Google Photos, but Id also like to edit certain shots and albums with my desktop photo-editing program. How do I grab those photos back from Google?

title: Owners Manual, Out of the Glove Box and Onto the App
description: THE recent death of the actor Anton Yelchin has spurred a class-action lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler, maker of the 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee that rolled backward after he stepped out and crushed him.

title: A Mood-Ring Ingredient Makes Cocktails Change Color
description: Megan Deschaine, the bar manager at 492, a restaurant on King Street in Charleston, S.C., sometimes despairs that the Disco Sour, a cocktail that has never left her menu, is so popular that it will be on my tombstone.

title: Tour de France Is Ready to Roll With Chris Froome as the Favorite
description: Jean-Marie Leblanc should probably have been more concerned about doping in cycling. His time as director of the Tour de France included the 1998 police raids that almost shut down cyclings most famous race as well as Lance Armstrongs now-erased record of seven straight wins.

title: Veteran Pollsters to Join Donald Trumps Campaign
description: Donald J. Trump will expand his roster of pollsters, with plans to add three new ones as his team shifts gears toward a general election with new urgency, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, July 2 Through July 10
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Poking at Politics, Without a Stick, on Big and Small Screens
description: The European postwar order is a shambles. A rich celebrity with no political experience and a flagrant disregard for the niceties of political behavior has become the presumptive nominee of a major American political party. Ill leave it there for now, though the litany of the dreadful, the unlikely, the inexplicable and the absurd could be extended in every direction. Over in the other major party, the wife of a former president fought off a serious challenge from a 74-year-old socialist. The political institutions that have taken turns governing Britain for most of the last century are in chaos. Lets not even talk about whats happening in Russia, Bolivia and Brazil. Who could make this stuff up?

title: Milk and Other Surprising Ways to Stay Hydrated
description: Most Americans have heard that they should drink eight glasses of water a day to stay hydrated, but there is surprisingly little data to support this advice.

title: Justice Department Wont Alter Music Industry Royalty Rules
description: The music industry sent a wish list to Washington, but the response was not quite what it had expected.

title: The Power of Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 2 Through July 10
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Seinfeldia, on Why We Still Cant Escape Hello, Jerry
description: Its not as if Seinfeld didnt have its critics. Writing in New York magazine, John Leonard called the show a Cheez Doodle of urban fecklessness. The New Republics longtime literary editor, Leon Wieseltier, a professional lowerer of the boom, said it was the worst, last gasp of Reaganite, grasping, materialistic, narcissistic, banal self-absorption. Newman, the shows villain, reduced these sentiments to two words: Hello, Jerry.

title: More Operatic Drama at Bayreuth as Andris Nelsons Pulls Out
description: The Bayreuth Festival in Germany, which Richard Wagner conceived to stage his operas, has a reputation for backstage drama that rivals its music dramas, and this year is no different. Andris Nelsons, one of the worlds leading conductors, announced Thursday that he had withdrawn from the new production of Parsifal that will open the festival next month.

title: Review: A Tarzan With a Few Twists in the Hollywood Vine
description: The Legend of Tarzan has a whole lot of fun, big-screen things going for it  adventure, romance, natural landscapes, digital animals and oceans of rippling handsome man-muscle. Its sweep and easy pleasures come from its old-fashioned escapades  its one long dash through the jungle by foot, train, boat and swinging vine  but what makes it more enjoyable than other recycled stories of this type is that the filmmakers have given Tarzan a thoughtful, imperfect makeover. That must have been tough given the origin storys white supremacy problems.

title: Video Review: Hyundais Plug-In Sonata Saves Fuel With Understatement
description: THE 2016 Hyundai Sonata Plug-in Hybrid should be an easy sell. At road speed, its hushed. It keeps sharp bumps from reaching your keister, is spacious for the car pool gang and conservatively handsome. And of course, its very fuel-efficient.

title: Fired VW Employee Withdraws Wrongful Dismissal Lawsuit
description: A former Volkswagen employee in Michigan has withdrawn a lawsuit claiming he was fired illegally because he was about to report the company for obstruction of justice, according to court documents.

title: After Soggy First Round, Restless Wimbledon Plays Catch-Up
description: WIMBLEDON, England  At 12:46 p.m. Thursday, when Barbora Strycova hit a forehand winner on Court 14 to beat Anett Kontaveit, the first round of Wimbledon finally ended.

title: Senator Mike Lee Unloads on Why He Cant Embrace Donald Trump
description: Donald J. Trump has asked Republicans who do not have anything nice to say about him to not say anything at all.

title: Housing Agency Overhauls Rules to Help Struggling Homeowners
description: A federal program that sold more than 100,000 soured mortgages to private investors at discounted prices is getting a major overhaul.

title: Costs of Regulations
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Next Lesson: Grner Veltliner
description: Remember grner veltliner? Of course you do.

title: Theres More to Ros Than You May Think
description: Summer arrives, and along with it, ros and enough wine clichs to float a cruise ship. You may have heard endless odes to the pink wine and its moment in the sun, how its not just a drink, its a lifestyle, and so on.

title: Tuskegee Study Findings
description: To the Editor:

title: All Eyes (and Ears) on Jupiter
description: As NASAs Juno spacecraft closes in for its Monday arrival at Jupiter, many other eyes are also staring at the solar systems largest planet.

title: Zlatan Ibrahimovic Says He Is Joining Manchester United
description: Zlatan Ibrahimovic announced on his social media accounts Thursday that he would be joining Manchester United next season, confirming weeks of reports that he would make Englands Premier League his new home.

title: The Challenges That Remain for L.G.B.T. People After Marriage Ruling
description: As L.G.B.T. Pride Month comes to an end, the massacre of 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., cast a pall over this years celebrations to commemorate milestones for the community.

title: The Illicit Perks of the M.D. Club
description: ONE of my patients recently had her request for a relatively common medication for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, Vyvanse, denied by her insurance provider. I tried to appeal the decision, but her father  the chief executive of a health care company who purchased insurance for hundreds of employees  had better luck. He called up the head of the insurance company and got the drug approved.

title: Garbie Muguruza and Dominic Thiem Join Exodus of Wimbledon Seeds
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Instead of rain, seeded players were falling Thursday at Wimbledon.

title: Parenting Our Children After We Die
description: Accounts of the grief children suffer after the deaths of their mothers or fathers reinforced my desire to use the time granted by treatment to help my adult children cope with my demise. We always parent our offspring to survive us, but cancer intensifies the urgency to do so.

title: 1891: Literary Copyrights Protected
description: President Harrison has been of late in frequent consultation with Mr. Spofford, the Librarian of Congress, and will soon issue the proclamation prescribed by the International Copyright Law. In anticipation of the new law coming into force, the Governments of Great Britain, France, Belgium and Switzerland have signified to the United States, through the proper diplomatic channels, their readiness to avail themselves of the facilities offered by the Act to their citizens for copyright here, and will grant to American authors privileges equal to those of their own citizens.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 1, 1891

title: The 5 Conservatives Vying to Become Britains Next Prime Minister
description: LONDON  Boris Johnsons surprising announcement on Thursday that he would not seek the leadership of the British Conservative Party  and by extension, succeed David Cameron as prime minister  leaves five candidates for the job.

title: Art by Jan Brady? Wally Cleaver? Lando Calrissian? See It Off Broadway
description: ROSIE ODONNELLS painting hangs high above the kitchen door. Below it is an abstract work by the Gilligans Island star Tina Louise. On the opposite wall hangs a gicle figure of a blues musician by Billy Dee Williams of Star Wars.

title: Reactions to West Bank Stabbing
description: A Palestinian infiltrated a Jewish settlement in the West Bank on Thursday and killed a teenage girl. The suspect was killed by a resident.

title: Calum McSwiggan, YouTube Star, Charged With Filing False Report
description: A popular host of YouTube videos about gay rights was charged in Los Angeles on Wednesday with filing a false report about being severely beaten outside a gay club, the authorities said.

title: A Rappers Killing Puts Baltimore, Grief-Stricken and Angry, on Edge
description: BALTIMORE  When riots broke out last year over the death of Freddie Gray, a promising young hip-hop artist named Lor Scoota, who rapped about selling scramble, coke and smack yet ran a football team for inner-city children, made the rounds of local high schools at the invitation of a city councilman. He told students to get their diplomas and shared his dream of escape.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: The News with Andrew Rosenthal
description: Times Insider shares insights into working and thinking at The New York Times. Today, Andrew Rosenthal, an opinion columnist with The Times, responds to recent news: the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

title: Transgender People Will Be Allowed to Serve Openly in Military
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter on Thursday removed one of the final barriers to military service by lifting the Pentagons ban on transgender people serving openly in the armed forces.

title: A Fairy-Tale Wedding, Castle Included
description: At the center of the romance: the lovers. Vying for equal attention these days: the castle.

title: 1971 | Supreme Court Allows Publication of Pentagon Papers
description: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, reflects on the 45th anniversary of the historic victory for freedom of the press.

title: How to Make Sure Your Overseas Wedding Is Legal
description: As romantic as it may be to wed in a castle in another country, it is important to pay attention to the laws of the land. Here are some tips to make sure your wedding is legal.

title: British Woman, 60, Wins Legal Round in Fight to Give Birth to Grandchild
description: LONDON  A 60-year-old woman determined to use her dead daughters frozen eggs to give birth to her own grandchild won a crucial legal victory on Thursday in second-highest court in Britain.

title: Preliminary Injunction Against Indiana Abortion Law
description: The preliminary injunction issued Thursday that blocked an Indiana law banning abortions sought because of a fetus's genetic abnormalities.

title: Ozone Hole Shows Signs of Shrinking, Scientists Say
description: Nearly three decades after the world banned chemicals that were destroying the atmospheres protective ozone layer, scientists said Thursday that there were signs the atmosphere was on the mend.

title: Nancy Grace to Leave HLN After More Than a Decade
description: Nancy Grace, the polarizing television personality who for more than a decade used her platform on the HLN network to aggressively cover tabloid crime stories, will leave the network in October.

title: Memorial at Istanbul Airport for Victims
description: Turkey held a day of mourning on Thursday to honor dozens killed in an attack at the Ataturk airport. The airport has since reopened, but travelers paused for a moment of silence and a short memorial.

title: 36 Hours in Cleveland
description: Whatever the fallout from the forthcoming Republican National Convention, Cleveland, with its booming food scene and revitalized downtown, is camera ready.

title: What Its Like to Cover Mass Shootings  One After the Other
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Julie Turkewitz, a reporter at The Times, describes what it is like to have covered a series of mass shootings.

title: Celebrating the National Park Centennial
description: Last year, the National Park Service shattered its previous attendance record by 14 million, attracting more than 307 million visitors. This year, traffic is already up nearly 3 million in year-to-date comparisons. And while the service wont project another record-breaking year, 2016 is shaping up to be perhaps its busiest summer, as judged by events created to celebrate its centennial year.

title: After Brexit, Finding a New London for the Financial World to Call Home
description: The race is on to be the new London.

title: How (and Why) to Camp in the National Parks
description: Chris Santella says he wasnt raised by outdoorsy parents. But as a young man growing up in Connecticut, with grandparents who lived in Maine, he developed a kinship with nature  in particular, a love for standing knee-deep in rivers and fly-fishing. The East Coaster ultimately moved West, settling in Portland, Ore., and put aside a corporate career in marketing to write about his outdoor adventures, including trips to at least a dozen national parks.

title: U.S. Warns Honda and Acura Owners to Replace Airbags
description: In an urgent plea to car owners, federal safety regulators on Thursday warned that airbags in more than 300,000 older Honda and Acura vehicles were at an unacceptably high risk of exploding, and needed to be replaced immediately.

title: An Alcohol-Laced Society
description: To the Editor:

title: MasterCard-Visa Settlement With Retailers Is Overturned
description: A federal appeals court on Thursday overturned a historic antitrust settlement between retailers and Visa and MasterCard, reviving more than a decade of legal battles over processing fees.

title: Donald Trump Warns of a Liberal Supreme Court if Hillary Clinton Wins
description: Donald J. Trump broke his silence on Thursday about the Supreme Courts decision to block parts of a Texas law restricting abortion access, promising that such outcomes would be different if he was elected president.

title: Still Want to Get the News on Facebook? Read All About It
description: Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would change its news feed algorithm to put a higher priority on content shared by friends and family. That most likely means you will see fewer articles, videos or photos shared by the media companies you follow on Facebook.

title: Russia Fires Dozens of Military Officers in Baltic Region
description: MOSCOW  In a sweeping military shake-up, Russia has replaced the top commanders of its Baltic Fleet, which patrols a region that has become the main fault line between Russia and the West.

title: Hershey Rejects Mondelezs $23 Billion Takeover Offer
description: For more than a century, Hershey  an American candy icon so well known it gave its name to its Pennsylvania hometown  has stood independent, rebuffing numerous attempts to buy the maker of Kisses and Reeses Peanut Butter Cups.

title: N.B.A. Free Agency: Whos Going Where
description: Over the last two seasons, the proposed solution to nearly every N.B.A. teams problems has been simple: Sign Kevin Durant when he hits free agency. Now that he is about to hit the open market, only a handful of teams will even have a chance to talk to him.

title: The World Bank and Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: When Pals Bash Their Spouses, Should You Speak Up?
description: My husband and I have two sets of longtime-couple friends whom we often see as a group. Recently, the wives (with little or no provocation) have taken to being sharp and nasty with their husbands. We are shocked by this because the offending remarks by the husbands are things that would usually cause us to laugh at each others foibles. The husbands seem embarrassed. I try to interject a new line of conversation. Should we continue to ignore this, or should I speak to the wives privately about how poorly their behavior reflects on them?

title: After the Brexit Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Animals Sly Enough to Surprise David Attenborough
description: It presumably takes quite a lot these days to surprise David Attenborough when it comes to nature programs, since he is a veteran of so many of them. But a plunging polar bear and a tiptoeing tiger, among other creatures, did the trick in Alastair Fothergills seven-part docu-series The Hunt, which begins Sunday on BBC America.

title: Italian Navy Recovers Ship Containing at Least 300 Migrants Bodies
description: ROME  The Italian authorities recovered from the bottom of the sea on Thursday a fishing vessel containing the remains of hundreds of migrants who drowned when the ship sank off the coast of Libya last year, a tragedy that spurred Europe to revive search-and-rescue operations in the Mediterranean.

title: Stop Bashing G.M.O. Foods, More Than 100 Nobel Laureates Say
description: More than 100 Nobel laureates have a message for Greenpeace: Quit the G.M.O.-bashing.

title: Review: A Sweet Take on British Identity Returns to PBS
description: I had not expected watching The Great British Baking Show to be a politically freighted experience. But that was before Brexit.

title: G.M.O.s in Food? Vermonters Will Know
description: Nearly all food labels in Vermont are now required to disclose when products include genetically engineered ingredients. The requirement, passed two years ago, became effective on Friday.

title: Lil Wayne Jail Memoir, Gone Til November, Due in October
description: At least one of Lil Waynes long-delayed projects now has a release date.

title: Quiet Fireworks Promise Relief for Children and Animals
description: Quiet fireworks  it sounds like an oxymoron. Usually those bright bursts of color come with equally impressive bangs. But some fireworks shows are designed to please the eyes without pummeling the ears.

title: ISIS Claims Killing of Coptic Christian Minister in Sinai
description: CAIRO  A gunman fatally shot a Christian minister on Egypts volatile Sinai Peninsula on Thursday, security officials said. The Islamic State, in a message distributed on social media, claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Swiss Army Man
description: Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, the writers and directors of Swiss Army Man, narrate a scene featuring Paul Dano and Daniel Radcliffe.

title: Swimmer David Plummer Can Finally Call Himself an Olympian
description: OMAHA  Four years ago, David Plummer touched the wall at the end of the 100-meter backstroke final at the United States Olympic swimming trials and looked up at the scoreboard. He placed third, missing the team by 12-hundredths of a second.

title: As Britain Faces Uncertainty, Europeans Jockey for Londons Business
description: Within hours of Britains vote to leave the European Union, it started.

title: Britain May Need to Cut Rates, Bank of England Chief Says
description: LONDON  The Bank of England may be forced to cut a key interest rate this summer as it grapples with economic uncertainty created by Britains vote to leave the European Union, Mark Carney, the banks governor, said in a speech on Thursday.

title: New Yorks Sidewalks Are So Packed, Pedestrians Are Taking to the Streets
description: Ivette Singh hardly bothers to walk on the sidewalk on her way to work in Midtown Manhattan anymore. Too many people, too little space. Not enough patience.

title: Daniels Narrate a Scene From Swiss Army Man
description: A man makes friends with a corpse in Swiss Army Man, the not-easy-to-classify debut feature from Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, professionally known as Daniels. When the film played at Sundance, it became known mostly for its flatulent corpse character. But it has since gone on to receive positive reviews in limited release. It expands to more theaters July 1. In one scene, the main character Hank (Paul Dano) tries to get his corpse friend, Manny (Daniel Radcliffe), to recall the joys of living by creating a makeshift bus and taking him for a ride.

title: Review: With Chests Held Proud, These Argentine Dancers Storm the Stage
description: BECKET, Mass.  An avid dancegoer is likely to cross paths every so often with flamenco, Irish dance, tango or tap, packaged and polished for the concert stage. Sightings of malambo, a cousin of those fleet-footed styles, are less common. It wasnt until City Centers Fall for Dance festival last year that I first encountered the form, a blend of drumming and percussive dance practiced by gauchos, or South American cowboys, since the 17th century. The dancers were the 14 men of Che Malambo, an Argentine company founded and directed by the French dancer Gilles Brinas, and they sent the audience into uproarious applause.

title: Adnan Syed, of Serial Podcast, Gets a Retrial in Murder Case
description: A judge in Maryland has granted a new trial to Adnan Syed, setting aside his conviction for the 1999 murder of his former girlfriend, in a case that was the subject of the first season of the hit podcast Serial.

title: Meeting Between Bill Clinton and Loretta Lynch Provokes Political Furor
description: WASHINGTON  An airport encounter this week between Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch and former President Bill Clinton has welled into a political storm, with Republicans asserting that it compromised the Justice Departments politically sensitive investigation into Hillary Clintons email practices while she was secretary of state.

title: Williams Faces Uphill Battle in Fight With Energy Transfer
description: The Wiliams Companies is in Delaware court, appealing the termination of a contentious deal to merge with the pipeline operator Energy Transfer Equity. But if you want to understand the chances the Williams Companies has in winning its appeal, you need to understand merger agreements.

title: Yankees Use a Passed Ball, Not a Long Ball, to Win Again in Ninth
description: For an encore on Thursday, the Yankees did it again  a walk-off victory over the Texas Rangers in the bottom of the ninth inning. Except this one was hardly as emphatic, with the Yankees scoring the winning run on a passed ball less than 24 hours after they had triumphed on Wednesday night on a two-run home run by Didi Gregorius.

title: The Macroeconomics of Brexit: Motivated Reasoning?
description: Im still on vacation, but had some time to catch up today, and felt an urge to scratch an itch Ive been feeling. You see, much of the discussion of Brexit and its impacts bothers me. I believe that Brexit is a tragic development, which will do substantial long-run economic harm. But what were hearing overwhelmingly from economists is the claim that it will also have severe short-run adverse impacts. And that claim seems dubious.

title: Review: Revisiting an Unlikely Campaign in Roseanne for President!
description: Politics meets celebrity in Eric Weinribs fascinating documentary Roseanne for President!, a record of Roseanne Barrs pursuit of a spot on the Green Partys national ticket in 2012. Ms. Barr, of course, starred in the groundbreaking, Emmy-winning sitcom Roseanne (1988-1997), one of the first network shows to include gay characters and offer a comparatively realistic depiction of a working-class family. A campaign, we discover, is a very different vehicle.

title: Self-Driving Tesla Was Involved in Fatal Crash, U.S. Says
description: DETROIT  The race by automakers and technology firms to develop self-driving cars has been fueled by the belief that computers can operate a vehicle more safely than human drivers.

title: Review: Once Lost, Private Property Is a Genuine Rediscovery
description: This 1960 picture, long considered lost, and newly restored courtesy of the bold indie distributor Cinelicious Pics, is a sex-crime thriller that teeters on the edge of morbidity before its galvanic climax. Seen today, its also a fascinating mlange of cinematic semiotics.

title: Reassembling Hamilton Palace, Room by Room, All 150 of Them
description: A domed mausoleum and some ghosts of cellars are all that remain of Hamilton Palace, once considered one of the most imposing homes in Britain. After a visit in 1706, the writer Daniel Defoe described it as fit rather for the Court of a Prince than the Palace or House of a Subject.

title: Review: Bruce Willis Is a Banker With Issues in Marauders
description: Folks complain a lot these days about the excess of superhero movies, but thats not the most nettlesome glut in the overcrowded movie scene. What about overbaked, mediocre thrillers trading on the marquee value of one or more big-name lead actors (almost always male), who, in turn, phone in performances of perfunctorily written roles?

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, July 2 Through July 10
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Review: In Life, Animated, a Bound Mind Finds Freedom
description: The disparity between what we want for our children and what they might achieve can be especially painful for parents of autistic youngsters. Yet youd barely know that from Roger Ross Williamss relentlessly cheerful documentary, Life, Animated. Like the Disney movie clips that flood its frames, this too-tentative look at how a bound mind found freedom in animation leaves us in little doubt of a happy ending.

title: Review: In Carnage Park, the Hills Have Eyes, and a Sniper, Too
description: Mickey Keating takes the adage less is more to heart in his Carnage Park, and it pays off pretty well. This no-frills horror film about a murderous psycho who terrorizes people unlucky enough to wander into his corner of California hill country has no fancy special effects or supernatural goings-on. Its dialogue would probably fit on a couple of sheets of paper. But it sure is creepy, in a throwback sort of way.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Art in review, from Times critics.

title: Review: A Sleeping Beauty Revival Rich in Details and Rewards
description: Young dancers with American Ballet Theater have been taking to new roles this week like ducks to water. The company is playing Alexei Ratmanskys production of The Sleeping Beauty, new last year; the choreography, to a large extent, is not Mr. Ratmanskys but by Marius Petipa, restored from records of the 1890 original and with a startling command of period style. Experienced dancers have matured. Multiple interpreters have found different rewards from the same roles. The production, running all this week at the tail end of Ballet Theaters eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, is looking even better than it did in its premiere season.

title: Review: The Purge: Election Year Offers a Campaign Platform of Blood Lust
description: The Purge is a scrappy little franchise  three movies so far  built on a solid premise. In a dystopian future (the only kind we get these days), the American government has decreed that one night a year will be given over to lawlessness. Otherwise responsible citizens can unleash their blood lust in an orgy of mayhem without consequences.

title: A Remark on Israel by Jeremy Corbyn Incites Outrage in Britain and Abroad
description: LONDON  Trying to address accusations of anti-Semitism in Britains opposition Labour Party, its embattled leader, Jeremy Corbyn, provoked more outrage on Thursday by comparing Israel to self-styled Islamic states or organizations.

title: Review: A Professor Drawn to the Mob in Our Kind of Traitor
description: Every so often, a news story shows up that seems to beg for fictionalization. Its no wonder that so many journalists love playing make-believe producers, as when they write that the news theyre covering has all the makings of a Hollywood movie. These days, though, the major American movie studios are more in the business of comic-book intrigues than in realism. Even so, the continued trickle of adaptations of John le Carrs work (including the recent miniseries The Night Manager) suggests that someone still believes that theres a market for adult stories about real-world stakes.

title: This Weeks Movies: July 1, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review The BFG, The Legend of Tarzan and Our Kind of Traitor.

title: A Sleeping Beauty Kind of Day
description: Cassandra Trenary, a soloist for American Ballet Theater, danced her New York City debut as Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty on Wednesday. First, though, she had class.

title: Tony Ourslers Grand Illusions, Science Left at the Door
description: In Paris in the early 1780s, Franz Anton Mesmer was attracting attention for his showy demonstrations of mesmerism, or what would later be called hypnotism. King Louis XVI appointed a commission that included Benjamin Franklin, Americas ambassador to France, to investigate.

title: Cassandra Trenary on Having (Just) Danced The Sleeping Beauty
description: To conquer Aurora is proof that a dancer is on her way to becoming a ballerina. On Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, Cassandra Trenary killed it.

title: Bruce Conners Darkness That Defies Authority
description: Bruce Conner was one of the great outliers of American art, a polymathic nonconformist whose secret mantra might have been Only resist. In multiple media, over more than five decades, this restless denizen of the San Francisco cultural scene resisted categorization, art world expectations and almost any kind of authority.

title: Istanbul, Donald Trump, Boris Johnson: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Lionsgates Deal for Starz Bears Malones Hallmarks
description: The movie studio Lionsgates $4.4 billion deal to acquire the pay-TV company Starz has media mogul John C. Malones fingerprints all over it. A complex structure? Check. New governance-skewing nonvoting stock? Yup. More influence for the man known as the Cable Cowboy? You bet. Starz shareholders should not be surprised at the modest premium on the offer.

title: Obama Picks New York Architects to Design Presidential Library
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and the team planning his life after the White House have selected Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, a New York-based husband-and-wife architectural duo, to design his presidential library in Chicago, tapping two modernists who are known for their refined work creating cultural and academic institutions.

title: Lacking Brains, Plants Can Still Make Good Judgments About Risks
description: Plants may not be getting enough credit. Not only do they remember when you touch them, it turns out that they can make risky decisions that are as sophisticated as those made by humans, all without brains or complex nervous systems. And they may even judge risks more efficiently than we do.

title: Review: A House Car? For Microbe and Gasoline, Its Freedom
description: Lets face it. Were not exactly normal: you the hopeless romantic and me the grease monkey, declares Tho (Thophile Baquet), the scruffier of two likable adolescent misfits who gallivant around France in a homemade vehicle. That souped-up car, constructed from junk that includes a discarded carburetor that Theo repairs, is the real star of Michel Gondrys good-natured coming-of-age road movie, Microbe and Gasoline. With additions, this crude motorized buggy becomes a zany wooden mobile home. No matter that its limited horsepower requires it to be pushed up hills; it promises unlimited freedom on the open road.

title: Edward Snowden Will Join Daniel Radcliffe in Privacy, via Video
description: Be not afeard, indeed.

title: Review: In The Innocents, Not Even Nuns Are Spared War Horrors
description: Much of Anne Fontaines blistering film The Innocents is set within the walls of a Polish convent in December 1945, just after the end of World War II. What at first appears to be an austere, holy retreat from surrounding horrors is revealed to be a savagely violated sanctuary awash in fear, trauma and shame. The snow-covered, forested landscape of the convent is photographed to suggest an ominous frontier that offers no refuge from marauding outsiders.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: New York City Council Delays Scrutiny of Deed Changes
description: When New York City agreed to remove a deed restriction on a nursing home on the Lower East Side in exchange for $16.15 million, it did not foresee all the complications that would follow.

title: The Many Faces of Alexander Hamilton, Just in Time for the Fourth
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda may have announced that hes leaving the Broadway show Hamilton on July 9. But Alexander Hamilton himself, as local museums and libraries are eager to remind people, is hardly leaving New York City.

title: Celebrating Bison, Two Zoos Offer a Wild and Woolly Weekend
description: Eagles are notoriously defensive about their nests. You have to wonder what one would do if a bison lumbered up and suddenly wanted to share the space.

title: Theater Listings for July 1-7
description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

title: Auctioneer at Sothebys Confident in London as Art Hub
description: Early this week, when the art world braced for the potential fallout from Brexit, at least one auctioneer was resolute.

title: Why Will Markets Recover From Brexit? Clues From Past Crises
description: The markets looked very shaky when Britain voted on June 23 to leave the European Union. They have firmed up nicely since then.

title: U.N. Panel Moves to Curb Bias Against L.G.B.T. People
description: GENEVA  The United Nations main human rights body on Thursday adopted measures to strengthen protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, despite fierce resistance from Muslim and African countries.

title: Comedy Listings for July 1-7
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Transgender Troops Protected at Last
description: Shortly after the Pentagon began allowing openly gay people to serve in the military in 2011, a small group of transgender veterans quietly began to plan for the next battle. They thought it would take 15 years, perhaps more, for the military to openly accept transgender people in uniform.

title: Wright Concedes to Espaillat in Primary for House Seat
description: State Assemblyman Keith L. T. Wright conceded defeat on Thursday in the Democratic congressional primary to replace Representative Charles B. Rangel, shaking hands with the winner, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, who is on track to become the first Dominican immigrant to be elected to Congress.

title: Christies Defining British Art Brings Out Bidders
description: LONDON  With the art world still wondering about the long-term impact of Britains vote to exit from the European Union, Christies themed evening sale on Thursday, Defining British Art, seemed to prove that buyers are still out there for top works.

title: Zenefits Compensates Investors Over Past Misconduct
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Zenefits investors are getting a larger piece of the troubled human resources start-up because they overpaid for their stakes, unaware that the companys sales teams flouted regulations to enhance growth, Zenefits announced on Thursday. The move will cut the companys valuation in half, to about $2 billion.

title: Boris Johnson and the Years of a Clown
description: London  THE problem with spending your whole life pretending to be a buffoon is that eventually people start to believe you.

title: Classical Music Listings for July 1-7
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
